did.abstract: Correspondence, writings, research, and collected materials of Vittorio Re, Chief Chancellor of the Italian Consulate in Detroit, and noted author and lecturer on the history and experiences of the Italian-American community in Detroit and the state of Michigan.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: Collection received from Vittorio Re (donor no. 10307)in January, 2010.

accruals.p: No further additions to the papers are expected.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is not held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Vittorio Re papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Vittorio Re entered the Italian Consular Service on April 15, 1933 as administrative assistant at the Italian Consulate General of Sydney, Australia. After serving in the Italian Consulate General in Dubrovnic, Yugoslavia and the Italian Foreign Ministry Rome, he was appointed Chief Chancellor of the Italian Consulate in Detroit, Michigan, where his main interests were in commercial, cultural, and community relations.

Re holds an Italian Diploma in Education from the Teachers Training Institute in Rome and a B.A. in History from Wayne State University, Detroit, Michigan. He was a Knight in the Order of Merit of the Italian Republic.

After his retirement in 1977 he dedicated his time to researching the life of Italians in Michigan. His first effort was a history of the First Italian Presbyterian Church, followed by research on numerous topics related to the Italians of Michigan and the city of Detroit.

scopecontent.p: The Vittorio Re collection includes personal and professional papers, as well as collected materials, related to Mr. Re's position as Chief Chancellor of the Italian Consulate in Detroit, and his research and writings on the Italian community in Michigan and Detroit. The collection is especially rich with material about life and activities of Italian communities in Michigan, prominent Americans of Italian decent, as well as discrimination and stereotypes faced by the members of Italian American community. The papers are arranged in the following series: Correspondence and Notes; Papers, Speeches, and Research; and Collected Materials.
The Correspondence and Notes series includes both personal and professional letters as well some of Re's notes, covering the period from 1952 to 2002.

Papers, Speeches, and Research contains assignments and papers written by Re while a student at Wayne State University; papers and speeches written during his professional career as Chief Chancellor of the Italian Consulate; and papers about the history of Italians in the city of Detroit and the state of Michigan written after his retirement in 1977. Handwritten notes, publications, and printed materials collected by Re to support his writings are included.

scopecontent.p: Collected Materials contains brochures, publicity materials, notes, and correspondence associated with Italian organizations, as well as events in the Italian community of Michigan. The collection includes information about the bylaws, membership, elections, and events of the Michigan chapter of the American Italian Historical Association. Materials on the 500th anniversary celebration of Columbus Day are included, 700th anniversary of Dante, and 100th anniversary of Garibaldi's death. There are numerous newspaper clippings in English and Italian associated with events, people, and issues relevant to the Italian community in Detroit and Michigan. Also, papers of Armand L. DeGaetano, given to Mr. Re by DeGaetano. Armand DeGaetano was Professor of Italian at Wayne State University in Detroit, active member and leader of a number of Italian American organizations concerned with teaching of the Italian language and culture in the United States and in Michigan in particular. Papers include correspondence, personal and professional files, and heavily annotated and edited draft manuscript of a 1954 biography of Giovanni Battista Gelli by Lucy Moore (?), sent to DeGaetano by the author.
